article.description:
Maybe Pittsburgh's biggest mistake before
playing No. 2 Connecticut was failing to bring in upset expert
Dwight Clay to deliver a pep talk.
article.headline: Rebounding power and balance offense lifts UConn
article.linkText: UConn runs winning streak to 57 by ripping Pitt
article.story:
PITTSBURGH (AP) -- Maybe Pittsburgh's biggest mistake before
playing No. 2 Connecticut was failing to bring in upset expert
Dwight Clay to deliver a pep talk.

	   Connecticut used an overwhelming edge on the backboards and a
balanced offense led by Jessica Moore's 18 points to extend its
record winning streak to 57 with a 76-55 victory over Pittsburgh on
Saturday night.

	   UConn enjoyed a better late-January fate than men's
record-holder UCLA did. It was 29 years ago this week that Clay's
baseline jumper gave Notre Dame a 71-70 upset of UCLA, ending the
Bruins' 88-game winning streak.

	   Clay lives just a few blocks from Pitt's new Petersen Events
Center, but didn't attend the UConn game -- he was busy officiating
a boys high school game.

	   ''I don't know what our players think about it,'' Connecticut
coach Geno Auriemma said. ''I just know I think we're going to lose
every game and they think we're going to win every game. Neither
one of us is right.''

	   This night, the players were -- as usual. The Lady Huskies (18-0,
6-0 Big East) quickly opened a 12-point lead and maintained
double-digit leads throughout, mostly because Pitt rarely got more
than one shot on any possession.

	   UConn held a 56-21 rebounding edge, led by Ashley Battle's 13,
and a commanding 26-3 advantage in offensive rebounds. Since being
outrebounded by Virginia Tech 33-26 in a 69-57 UConn victory on
Jan. 12, the Lady Huskies have 81 more rebounds than their last
four opponents.

	   ''We're working at it, and we're playing some bad rebounding
teams,'' Auriemma said. ''We're playing teams more our size now.
But we've also worked harder at it.''

	   Diana Taurasi added 14 points and nine rebounds for UConn
despite a below-average 5-for-13 shooting night, Barbara Turner had
13 points and eight rebounds and Maria Conlon had 10 points. Moore
also had nine rebounds.

	   ''We want to dominate the boards,'' Battle said. ''The last few
games, we've been doing that.''

	   With Pitt's offense limited mostly to outside shots, the
Panthers never got the biggest crowd to watch a women's game in
Pittsburgh -- a standing room turnout of 12,632 -- into the game.

	   Connecticut jumped out to leads of 14-6, 20-8, 28-10 and 39-20
in winning its 16th in a row over Pittsburgh, a streak that dates
to 1993. UConn's 69-point margin of victory in its 112-43 rout of Pitt last season at Storrs is its largest during
the winning streak.

	   Asked again about the streak, Auriemma said, ''We beat Joe
DiMaggio'' -- a reference to the Hall of Famer's 56-game hitting
streak.

	   Pitt coach Traci Waites couldn't come up with a team that might
end the streak any time soon.

	   ''I'm speechless,'' Waites said. ''They were just so much bigger
and stronger. They've got a lot of freshmen, but I thought I was
looking at last year's (national championship) team.''

	   Despite Laine Selwyn's 16 points and Mandy Wittenmyer's 15,
Pittsburgh (9-8, 1-5) lost its fifth in six games since an 8-3
start that included an overtime upset of rival Penn State.

	   With all tickets priced at $1, a crowd that included hundreds of
Pittsburgh-area girls high school players was about 12,200 larger
than the 430 who attended the Miami-Pitt women's game Wednesday.
Until Saturday, the Pitt women's largest home crowd this season was
1,876 for Penn State.

	   The crowd also was the largest to see a game -- men's or women's
-- since Pitt's new, on-campus Petersen Events Center opened in late
November.

	   ''It was great to see them and it was great to see them stay,''
Waites said. ''They didn't have to. I just wish we could have
played a better game for them.''

	   UConn, however, is accustomed to playing before such crowds; it
was only the seventh-largest to watch the Lady Huskies this season.

	   Connecticut has played before the two largest crowds to see a
women's game in Pittsburgh. Their 2001 NCAA East Regional
appearance drew 9,397 to Mellon Arena.
